metadata.title: Locating Boston's Public Schools
metadata.author: Riley Thompson
metadata.subtitle: A look at Boston's public schools in the period before the American Revolution

caption.text: This map was created by William Price in 1769 and it provides an incredibly detailed illustration of Boston's layout.
caption.title: A new plan of ye great town of Boston in New England in America, with the many additionall [sic] buildings, & new streets, to the year, 1769

caption.text: This key includes four of Boston's five schools. It excludes the North Writing School.
caption.title: The Key

caption.text: Depicted here is the South Grammar School, known today as the Boston Latin School. The school is identified with the word "school" and the letter "c," which corresponds to the key.
caption.title: South Grammar School

caption.text: Depicted here is the North Grammar School. The school is identified by the "d" with the word "school" off to the left due to space restrictions.
caption.title: North Grammar School

caption.text: The North Writing School was located off of Love Lane, on the same plot of land as the North Grammar School, marked on the map with "d." However, the school is not included on the map. Price may have combined the two schools into one since they shared the same plot of land, even though they were two different buildings.
caption.title: North Writing School

caption.text: The location of the Queen Street Writing School is supposed to be marked with "e," however, "e" is not visible anywhere on the map. According to historical record, the school was located on the island like shape depicted here. Even though there is no "school " or "e" in the general area to identify this as the school's location, it is. The reason behind the absence of these markers is unknown.
caption.title: Queen Street Writing School

caption.text: This is the location of the South Writing School. It is identified by the presence of "school" and "f," which is the corresponding key entry.
caption.title: South Writing School
